Internet you would do an API request so jQuery AJAX or fetch or WebSockets or
something along those lines so you're asynchronously loading something from some other place because
you don't know how long it's gonna take and then once it's done do something else fairly standard web 101 type stuff load
some collection of widgets from some server elsewhere that you don't care about it actually helps to do that with
electron two except instead of hitting an external server you're hitting the wrapper chrome around your application
and you do that through something called IPC this might remember this from the

the boundary between our browser window and our electron chrome so let me show

for JavaScript modules anytime you do require it's actually bringing in a separate module and then you can

the electron shell is called main is actually the browser part it's the thing
that that renders your your webpage IPC renderer is the thing that render
is the thing that renders your webpage this is why I always get confused but IPC renderer is kind of the shell around
your app and then IPC main is your JavaScript app and so with me so far more or less okay
so inside our IPC main we can say
whenever there is a request then here's a callback for it so this is fairly

callbacks this is to enable that sort of async nature so we're not gonna actually

the EVT parameter is the event object that gives us a reference to in this

is our parameter and the electron reply is the name of the event so if you're familiar with any kind of jQuery this is

to get a reference to the renderer which again is the chrome the electron part
and whenever it gets a reply from that object then do something so in this case
we're going to do a console.log require received logout the reply and then we're
going to send it the Ember request so this is the actually make the asynchronous request part which this
handler is going to execute and then send back the reply of yay and then we
get reply receive da written out to the console so this is one way of doing
asynchronous operations between the browser frame and its containing Chrome
and one place that this works out well is something like this so FS is a file
system module for node and in this case what we're doing is reading a directory of files and then sending out the list
of those files back to the consuming application now excuse me it is possible
to require FS directly in your client code so I could go into the ember side I
could write require FS I could do reader from from FS and actually have all of
that happen but there's two main reasons why I tend not to do that one because you're doing filesystem access from your
rendering page it can actually make your app slightly unresponsive slow it down a
bit there's there's some concerns about performance in that case the containing
page the chrome is a lot more prepared to handle those types of requests so I
tend to offload those to the the electron shell itself the other reason
is especially if you're using JavaScript frameworks that are designed to help you
reuse code over a bunch of different projects you don't want to tie yourself to a file system implementation on your
client code because this might be the only place in your application stack where you're referencing the file system

minimize on the Left windows puts them on the right so don't put any elements on the right and then expect it to look
